thread.title: ‘Fancy Nancy’ author to greet fans at Bookmarks and DCT
thread.title_full: ‘Fancy Nancy’ author to greet fans at Bookmarks and DCT | Dallas Morning News

author: Churnin
title: ‘Fancy Nancy’ author to greet fans at Bookmarks and DCT
text:
Fancy Nancy fans owe a debt of gratitude to Jane O’Connor’s mother.
“My mother was very pretty and very chic, but she dressed in an understated way which I thought was plain as a little girl,” O’Connor says on the phone from her office at Penguin Books for Young Readers in New York, where she’s worked as an editor for 25 years.
“I was always trying to get her to look like the mother of a friend of mine who was very blond and wore pink iridescent lipstick and lots of jewelry.”
O’Connor — who created a sensation in 2005 with her first picture book about a little girl, not unlike the one she used to be, who tries to make the world more glamorous with glitter and fancy words — will be the star of a 90-minute celebration Saturday at Bookmarks, a Dallas public library branch in NorthPark Center. From there she’s off to Dallas Children’s Theater to catch a 4:30 p.m. performance of Fancy Nancy: The Musical.
A longtime writer, she says it took her by surprise when Fancy Nancy became a sensation, with more than 60 books in various formats, from picture to chapter books, selling more than 28 million copies for Harper Collins in the U.S.
“People sometimes will say to me, ‘Did you know you were going to write a best-selling kids’ book?’ and I think to myself, if I’d known, I would have done it 30 years earlier.”
Like Nancy, O’Connor loved to dress up and perform for company when she was little. O’Connor had a younger sister, Jill, who became the inspiration for Nancy’s little sister, Jo Jo. Jill, O’Connor notes proudly, grew up to become Jill Abramson, the first female executive editor of The New York Times . Abramson is now lecturing at Harvard University and collaborating with her sister on a new children’s book.
O’Connor credits her editor at Harper Collins, Margaret Anastas, for seeing the potential of Fancy Nancy before she did. It was Anastas who insisted it be illustrated by Robin Preiss Glasser, who gave Nancy her signature frilly look.
The key to Nancy is that she’s exuberant and gets excited and carried away, but when things don’t go as planned she’s resilient and learns what’s important, O’Connor says. In Fancy Nancy: The Musical at DCT, adapted from her book Fancy Nancy and the Mermaid Ballet , Nancy doesn’t get the starring role she wants, but finds she can still have a thrilling time in the ensemble.
O’Connor is the mother of two boys, now grown. Part of the fun is to find herself surrounded by exuberant young girls decked out in tiaras and tutus.
“It’s like dessert. I may have to put on a few boas and purple suede high heels.”
Plan your life
10:30 a.m. Saturday: Fancy Nancy party at Bookmarks. Paper Source will present paper-doll crafts and there’ll be tiaras, feather boas, top hats and bow ties for kids to play dress-up; 11 a.m.: sneak peek of Dallas Children’s Theater’s Fancy Nancy musical; 11:30 a.m.: Jane O’Connor will read books and answer questions. There’ll be a costume contest, a book giveaway and a signing. Bookmarks at NorthPark Center, 8687 N. Central Expressway, Dallas. Free. Includes a few minutes of the Fancy Nancy show from Dallas Children’s Theater.
4:30 p.m. Saturday: Additional performance of Fancy Nancy at Dallas Children’s Theater with autographs from 3 to 4:15 p.m. only (available to kids who line up before 4:15 p.m.) at Rosewood Center for Family Arts, 5938 Skillman St., Dallas, $15-$23 for Saturday show. Performances continue through Oct. 25. $15-$28. 214-740-0051. dct.org.
